Kidney Disease: Improving Global Outcomes. org What the guideline covers Target population: all adults and children identified with chronic kidney disease who are not on renal replacement therapy. chronic kidney disease: any (or unknown) cause. Target audience: nephrologists, primary care physicians, non-nephrology specialists, clinical chemists and other practitioners caring for adults and children with chronic kidney disease. Target healthcare settings: primary, secondary and tertiary care. Kidney Disease: Improving Global Outcomes www. Kidney Disease: Improving Global Outcomes. org 1. 4 Evaluation of chronic kidney disease: chronicity 1. 4. 1: Evaluation of Chronicity 1. 4. 1. 1: In people with glomerular filtration rate 60 milliliters per minute/1. 73m2 or markers of kidney damage, review past history and previous measurements to determine duration (Not Graded). If duration is 3 months, chronic kidney disease is confirmed. Follow recommendations for chronic kidney disease. If duration is not 3 months or unclear, chronic kidney disease is not confirmed. Patients may have chronic kidney disease or acute kidney diseases (including acute kidney injury) or both and tests should be repeated accordingly. Kidney Disease: Improving Global Outcomes www. (1A) 1. 4. 3. 2: We suggest using additional tests (such as cystatin C or a clearance measurement) for confirmatory testing in specific circumstances when estimated glomerular filtration rate based on serum creatinine is less accurate. Kidney Disease: Improving Global Outcomes. org 2. 1 Definition and identification of chronic kidney disease progression 2. 1. 1: Assess glomerular filtration rate and albuminuria at least annually in people with chronic kidney disease. Assess glomerular filtration rate and albuminuria more often for individuals at higher risk of progression, and/ or where measurement will impact therapeutic decisions. (Not Graded) Kidney Disease: Improving Global Outcomes www. Kidney Disease: Improving Global Outcomes. org Guide to frequency of monitoring (number of times per year) by glomerular filtration rate and albuminuria category Kidney Disease: Improving Global Outcomes www. Kidney Disease: Improving Global Outcomes. org chronic kidney disease progression 2. 1. 3: Define chronic kidney disease progression based on one of more of the following (Not Graded): Decline in glomerular filtration rate category (≥90 G1, 60-89 G2, 45-59 G3a, 30-44 G3b, 15-29 G4, 15 G5 milliliters per minute/1. 73m2). A certain drop in estimated glomerular filtration rate is defined as a drop in glomerular filtration rate category accompanied by a 25% or greater drop in estimated glomerular filtration rate from baseline. Rapid progression is defined as a sustained decline in estimated glomerular filtration rate of more than 5 mL/1. 73m2/year. The confidence in assessing progression is increased with increasing number of serum creatinine measurements and duration of follow-up. Kidney Disease: Improving Global Outcomes www. Kidney Disease: Improving Global Outcomes. org Blood Pressure 3. 1. 1: Individualize blood pressure targets and agents according to age, coexistent cardiovascular disease and other comorbidities, risk of progression of chronic kidney disease, presence or absence of retinopathy (in chronic kidney disease patients with diabetes), and tolerance of treatment as described in the Kidney Disease: Improving Global Outcomes 2012 Blood Pressure Guideline. (Not Graded). See Kidney Disease: Improving Global Outcomes Clinical Practice Guideline for the Management of Blood Pressure in Chronic Kidney Disease. Kidney Int Suppl December 2012; Vol. 2 (5) Kidney Disease: Improving Global Outcomes www. Kidney Disease: Improving Global Outcomes. org Blood Pressure 3. 1. 4: We recommend that in both diabetic and nondiabetic adults with chronic kidney disease and urine albumin excretion 30 magnesium/24 hours (or equivalent) whose office blood pressure is consistently 140 mm Hg systolic or 90 mm Hg diastolic be treated with blood pressure-lowering drugs to maintain a blood pressure that is consistently ≤140 mm Hg systolic and ≤90mm Hg diastolic. (1B) Kidney Disease: Improving Global Outcomes www. Kidney Disease: Improving Global Outcomes. org CDK Risk of AK I 3. 1. 12: We recommend that all people with chronic kidney disease are considered to be at increased risk of acute kidney injury. (1A) 3. 1. 12. 1: In people with chronic kidney disease the recommendations detailed in the Kidney Disease: Improving Global Outcomes acute kidney injury Guideline should be followed for management of those at risk of acute kidney injury during inter-current illness, or when undergoing investigation and procedures that are likely to increase the risk of acute kidney injury. Kidney Disease: Improving Global Outcomes. org Protein Intake 3. 1. 13: We suggest lowering protein intake to 0. 8 g/kg/day in adults with diabetes (2C) or without diabetes (2B) and glomerular filtration rate 30 milliliters per minute/1. 73m2 (glomerular filtration rate categories G4G5), with appropriate education. 3. 1. 14: We suggest avoiding high protein intake (1. 3 g/ kg/day) in adults with chronic kidney disease at risk of progression. (2C) Kidney Disease: Improving Global Outcomes www. Kidney Disease: Improving Global Outcomes. org Glycemic Control 3. 1. 15: We recommend a target hemoglobin hemoglobin A1c (hemoglobin hemoglobin A1c) of 7. 0% (53 mmol/mol) to prevent or delay progression of the microvascular complications of diabetes, including diabetic kidney disease. (1A) 3. 1. 16: We recommend not treating to an hemoglobin hemoglobin A1c target of 7. 0% (53 mmol/mol) in patients at risk of hypoglycemia. (1B) 3. 1. 17: We suggest that target hemoglobin hemoglobin A1c be extended above 7. 0% (53 mmol/mol) in individuals with comorbidities or limited life expectancy and risk of hypoglycemia. (2C) Kidney Disease: Improving Global Outcomes www. Kidney Disease: Improving Global Outcomes. org Salt Intake 3. 1. 12: We recommend lowering salt intake to 90 mmol (2 g) per day of sodium (corresponding to 5 g of sodium chloride) in adults, unless contraindicated. (1C) Kidney Disease: Improving Global Outcomes www. Kidney Disease: Improving Global Outcomes. org Hyperuricemia 3. 1. 13: There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of agents to lower serum uric acid concentrations in people with chronic kidney disease and either symptomatic or asymptomatic hyperuricemia in order to delay progression of chronic kidney disease. (Not Graded) Kidney Disease: Improving Global Outcomes www. Kidney Disease: Improving Global Outcomes. org Lifestyle 3. 1. 14: We recommend that people with chronic kidney disease be encouraged to take exercise (aiming for at least 30 minutes 5 times per week), achieve a healthy weight (body mass index 20-25, according to country specific demographics), and stop smoking.
